reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: I’ve always said, “Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing.” Amazon’s blend of complex cloud services, e-commerce logistics and digital media falls outside my tried-and-true circle, which focuses on simple consumer brands, railroads, banks, and insurance. I don’t fully grasp all the moving parts here, so I’d rather sit this one out. 2. Competitive Moat: While Amazon enjoys scale and a vast network effect, its inconsistent ROE—only 2 of the last 10 years above 15%—and a moat score of 1 suggest its advantage isn’t as enduring as Coca-Cola’s brand or Apple’s ecosystem. 3. Management Quality: I respect Jeff Bezos’s vision, but with no dividends and uncertain capital allocation in fast-burning growth areas, I see little evidence they’re acting like owners for smaller shareholders. 4. Financial Health & Consistency: A stellar ROE of 80.9% is eye-popping, yet the 14x debt-to-equity ratio and choppy earnings growth raise caution flags. Inconsistent profitability over time means I can’t rely on owner earnings compounding steadily, like we enjoy at See’s Candies or GEICO. 5. Valuation vs. Intrinsic Value: Your DCF pegs a conservative intrinsic value at $736 per share, implying a nearly 100% premium at current prices—there’s no margin of safety here. I’d rather buy a wonderful business at a fair price than a fair business at a wonderful price. 6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: While Amazon may survive and even thrive in pockets, the shifting retail landscape, regulatory scrutiny, and razor-thin margins in core commerce worry me. Complexity breeds risk—something I steer clear of. 7. Relative to Portfolio Opportunities: I’d much rather add to established holdings like Coca-Cola or Bank of America where the business models are straightforward, management teams are proven, and valuations allow a margin of safety. In short, I see too much complexity, not enough consistent results and no bargain to make this a ‘yes’ in my book.

fundamental_analysis.details: Strong ROE of 80.9%; High debt to equity ratio of 14.0; Strong operating margins; Current ratio data not available

consistency_analysis.details: Inconsistent earnings growth pattern; Total earnings growth of 1178.7% over past 10 periods

moat_analysis.details: Inconsistent ROE: only 2/10 periods >15%; Strong and stable operating margins (avg: 25.1%) indicate pricing power moat

book_value_analysis.details: Consistent book value per share growth (Buffett's favorite metric)

management_analysis.details: No significant new stock issuance detected; No or minimal dividends paid

details: Using three-stage DCF: Stage 1 (-3.5%, 5y), Stage 2 (-1.7%, 5y), Terminal (2.5%)
